7634 : Ballista is an exercise once used by the San d'Orian armies to train the Royal Knights in the art of the siege. The word ballista means to throw a stone, and the game has been a part of Vana'dielian military history for centuries.
7635 : The rules are simple. Ballista is played by two teams over a number of hours (Vana'diel time). The team with the most points at the end of the match is the victor.
7636 : Players from both teams must search for Petras that a Herald has buried in various locations across the battlefield. The players must then take these stones and throw them into targets known as Rooks.
7637 : These Rooks can appear in various locations around the battlefield, and both teams are allowed to throw their Petras into them.
7638 : Finally, a player's strength is adjusted depending on his or her level. It is felt that this ultimately allows for a more balanced battle.
7639 : Petras can be buried anywhere. Once a player believes he or she has found one, the Quarry (/quarry) command should be used to dig up the area at his or her feet.
7640 : Sometimes a player may find items other than Petras, such as potions. These temporary items can only be used during the current match (or Best of Three series).
7641 : Players can carry more than one Petra, but they cannot throw the stones away once they have obtained them. However, players will lose their Petras if they: (1) Successfully throw them into a rook. (2) Leave the area. (3) Are knocked out.
7642 : But don't forget, a player will be unable to use the Sprint command while in possession of a Petra. And, players can only use the Scout command if they carry one of the stones.
7643 : As one can see, careful planning and impeccable timing are the keys to victory.
7644 : All participants of Ballista will have the ability to use the Sprint command. This will temporarily increase one's movement speed, creating a better chance to find and obtain Petras.
7645 : However, remember that once a player has obtained a Petra, he or she will be unable to use the Sprint command. In its place, though, one may use the Scout command.
7646 : The locations of the Rooks are constantly changing. This makes it quite difficult to find the targets by just randomly walking about the area.
7647 : Communication with one's team members is, of course, one way to locate Rooks. However, another way is by using the Scout command. This will inform a player of the approximate location of the nearest Rook.
7648 : Finally, Scout can only be used when a player is carrying a Petra. Because Sprint cannot be used at this time, players must be weary of approaching enemies.
7649 : So, a Petra has been obtained and a Rook located. Now all that's left is tossing the stone in, right? Wrong.
7650 : There is one aspect of Ballista that has yet to be mentioned...and this is where the real battle begins.
7651 : To throw a Petra into a Rook, a player must first wait until the Rook's gate is open. This takes impeccable timing, as the gate is only open for a short while.
7652 : But not just anyone can score points this way. A player must first take down a member of the opposing team and achieve Gate Breach status. Only then will his or her shots count.
7653 : This extreme method of combat is what made the ancient game of Ballista famous, and transformed its participants into heroes.
7654 : Running about looking for stones is no different from a child's game of hide-and-seek. Knowing when to strike is what separates the men from the boys.
7655 : The following match types are area-specific: All or Nothing (one match) * Normal Items Allowed: Jugner Forest All or Nothing (one match) * Normal Items Restricted: Pashhow Marshlands Best of Three (three matches) * Normal Items Allowed: Meriphataud Mountains
7656 : Best of Three series rules are as follows: Winning a match will earn a nation one match point. The nation with the most match points at the end of the series will be declared the victor. Winning the third and final match and producing the high scorer will result in two match points awarded. This allows both sides the chance for come-from-behind victories.
7657 : Between each of the matches, a short interval will be implemented. During this interval, Invisible and Sneak will be cast on all participants. We suggest this time be used to discuss strategies with the other members of your nation's forces.
7658 : Players will be forbidden from using any items they bring to the battlefield. Only temporary items that are quarried may be used. A total of fifteen temporary items (though only one of each type) can be carried.
7659 : When this rule is in effect, all players will be presented with five complimentary temporary items at the beginning of the match.
7660 : For more information on temporary items, refer to the special rules.
7661 : After being KO'd, if a player chooses to be revived at the spot he was defeated, 100% of all HP and 50% of all MP will be restored. In addition, the player will maintain 50% of the TP he had earned.
7662 : If a player chooses to return to their force's camp, HP and MP will be fully restored, but all TP will be lost.
7663 : Please note that many of the rules previously considered special have been fully implemented. Also, several new special rules have been added.
7664 : Learn about which special rules? Temporary items. Ballista Points. Scoring restrictions. Gate Breach radius expansion. Resistance to Sleep. Open entries. Minimum level restrictions. Re-entry restrictions. Participant & Rook numbers. Experience Points. Return.
7665 : Previously, participants in Ballista were required to use an item the moment they dug it up using the /quarry command. However, players can now stock these items as temporary items for use at any time during the match.
7666 : Players can hold up to ten temporary items, but only one of each type. If a player finds an item that they already possess, they must use it immediately or throw it away.
7667 : If players who possess ten temporary items find an item that they have not already obtained, they will also have the option to exchange it with one of their current items.
7668 : Also, players will not, at any time, be allowed to trade temporary items. However, there are items that can be used on other Ballista participants. Please note that players may not be able to use these special items as soon as they are quarried.
7669 : Finally, the Heralds will collect temporary items when the match (the third in a Best of Three series) has concluded.
7670 : Ballista Points are rewarded to each competitor based on his or her performance in a single Ballista match. The maximum number of points that can be accumulated per match is #.
7671 : While it is taken into consideration, scoring Petras is not the only way to earn Ballista Points. Assisting allies and defeating members of the enemy forces can also earn a high score.
7672 : Ballista Points can be traded for special vouchers, which may be exchanged for free temporary items at the start of new matches.
7673 : However, remember that depending on the level restriction of the match, certain vouchers will not be redeemed at the beginning of a match. Speak with a Marshal directly after a match to register your points.
7674 : Players will only be allowed to score up to five Petras at a time. Also, a player's Gate Breach status will be automatically disengaged if a Petra is not scored within a certain amount of time. The amount of time is increased for those members of the team currently behind in points.
7675 : All allies within a certain radius will achieve Gate Breach status when a member of the enemy forces is defeated.
7676 : Players' resistance to sleep will be increased.
7677 : During the entry period, from #:, all adventurers will be allowed to join the forces with the smallest number of participants, regardless of allegiance. Open entries will be accepted until both sides have reached maximum capacity.
7678 : In order to ensure balanced matches, the following level limits are enforced: Level 30 matches: 130
7679 : Level 40 matches: 3140 Level 50 matches: 4150 Level 60 matches: 5160 Unrestricted matches: 61
7680 : Please note that any participant who cancels his or her registration will not be allowed to re-apply for the same match.
7681 : When the total number of participants in a match is less than 40, the location of the two camps will be adjusted. Also in this case, the number of Rooks will be reduced to two.
7682 : Any adventurer whose main level is over 30 will receive EXP for participating in a Ballista match. However, no EXP will be rewarded if the adventurer fails to actively take part in the match.
7683 : Read which chapter on B.P. Ranking? Basic Information. Registering Points. Rewards. Chevron & Title List. None.
7684 : Ballista Point Ranking is based upon all Ballista Points registered from the past ten matches in each of the three participating battle areas.
7685 : Anyone who wishes to take part in the ranking needs to register [his/her] points within four hours (Vana'diel time) from the end of the previous match.
7686 : After the registration period ends, players can compare their record with those of the previous nine matches.
7687 : If, at any time, a player ranks in the top ten (overall) or first for a specific job, [he/she] will have the opportunity to receive a special chevron as well as a new title.
7688 : There are four types of chevrons and titles awarded to top-ten players (gold/mythril/silver/bronze), as well as two different types awarded for outstanding performances by players of each of the twenty-two jobs.
7689 : Wearing a chevron during a Ballista match will automatically change a player's current title. If a player wishes to possess this title after a match as well, [he/she] must contact a certain bard in San d'Oria.
7690 : Also, while wearing a chevron, players will be able to trade Ballista Points for temporary items not available to all players.
7691 : However, the rules of Ballista state that players may only possess a certain chevron for no longer than one half Vana'diel year. When that time comes, they are required to return the chevron before being allowed to participate in any further matches.
7692 : Finally, checking someone during a Ballista match will display the total number of chevrons that person has accumulated to date.
7693 : View which chevron/title? 1st (overall). 2nd (overall). 3rd (overall). 4th-10th (overall). 1st (warrior). 1st (monk). 1st (white mage). 1st (black mage). 1st (red mage). 1st (thief). 1st (paladin). 1st (dark knight). 1st (beastmaster). 1st (bard). 1st (ranger). 1st (samurai). 1st (ninja). 1st (dragoon). 1st (summoner). 1st (blue mage). 1st (corsair). 1st (puppetmaster). 1st (dancer). 1st (scholar). 1st (geomancer). 1st (rune fencer). Return.

8020 : The hunt registry is a tome through which seasoned adventurers can undertake assignments to eliminate monsters deemed to be impediments to A.M.A.N. activities.
8021 : The hunt registry is a tome through which veteran soldiers can undertake assignments to eliminate monsters deemed to be impediments to S.M.A.N. activities.
8022 : Assignments, or hunts, can be undertaken simply by selecting the name of a monster listed in the registry.
8023 : Pertinent information such as monster elusiveness and ferocity has been recorded for your reference. As safety cannot be guaranteed, we ask that you hunt within your ability.
8024 : Hunts pit you against creatures of extreme ferocity, and are not intended for training. For this reason, you cannot undertake a hunt while a training regime is active.
8025 : Should party members undertaking a common hunt defeat the objective, the kill will be considered valid for all.
8026 : Upon the completion of a hunt, record your success in a hunt registry. Doing so will earn you rewards corresponding to difficulty as well as scylds--tokens of your valor.
8027 : More scylds will grant you access to increasingly difficult and rewarding assignments. Be warned, however, that once expended, scylds will not be refunded for any reason.
8028 : Lastly, please note that a mandatory cool-down period will be imposed upon all hunters following the completion of a hunt. Until this time has elapsed, you will not be permitted to undertake another hunt.

11627 : I will explain simply. Water puts out fire, whilst the heat of fire melts ice.
11628 : Ice blocks wind, whilst wind wears away at earth. Can you see it right there?
11629 : Earth steals energy from lightning, whilst lightning throws its bolts into water.
11630 : Light and darkness occupy the center. They are in mutual opposition, for one cannot be both at once.

11741 : What do you wish to know about? Nothing. Conquests. Conquest results. Donating crystals. Conquest points. The effects of controlling regions. Regions controlled by other nations. Regions under beastman control.
11742 : All three nations are striving daily to put more regions under their control. This is what we call conquests. You can take part in it and serve your country by defeating enemies while you have Signet cast on you.
11743 : Each region comprises several areas, and the nation that rids those areas of the most monsters gains control of the region.
11744 : Nations receive goods and resources from regions under their control.
11745 : So, the more regions we control, the richer our nation becomes.
11746 : Border guards are also placed in outposts within regions under our control. They are there to cast Signet on adventurers like yourself.
11747 : Once you have your nation's Signet, you will be able to acquire crystals from enemies you defeat.
11748 : Not only that, but you will also receive conquest points. You get more conquest points if you defeat enemies in regions that are not under your nation's control. These points can be used to purchase items from guards like myself.
11749 : So you see...conquests benefit nations and adventurers alike. We expect you to do your best to serve your country.
11750 : You can see the current state of conquests by selecting Region Info from the main menu. Conquest results in all regions are regularly recalculated, so you may want to check them from time to time.
11751 : Shops in our city will be selling different items according to our conquest rank. The Troupe Valeriano will also visit the nation that finishes first and bring a little joy to its citizens.
11752 : You can donate crystals to your nation once you achieve rank 2. Just trade them to guards like myself, and we will ensure they are sent to the proper place.

11755 : Rank points will be awarded to you for each crystal you donate, and you may be offered new missions as your rank goes up.
11756 : You also receive rank points for completing missions. Complete missions and take part in conquests to raise your rank and serve your country.
11757 : You are awarded conquest points when you defeat monsters while you are taking part in conquests. Select "Region Info" from the menu to check your current number of conquest points.
11758 : You can purchase items from guards like myself with your conquest points, but be warned that the number of points you spend will be subtracted from your current total.
11759 : When conquest results are announced, you will be told which country controls the region you are in at that time. Sometimes regions may become neutral, or beastmen may even gain control of regions.
11760 : If we gain control of a region, border guards will be placed at its outposts to help adventurers like you.
11761 : Merchants will also be placed there, and goods from that region will find their way to the local shops here.
11762 : Gaining control of regions is the basic principle behind conquests. We need each of you to do your best, and bring our nation to the top of the ranks.
11763 : Of course, sometimes we lose regions to other nations...so we must try to take them back before the next conquest results are announced.
11764 : As an incentive, we will award you with more conquest points for defeating monsters in those regions.
11765 : But if we are allied with another nation, you will only be awarded the regular rate for defeating monsters in our allies' regions. On the other hand, we will award you with more points for fighting in the top-ranked nation's regions.
11766 : Our paramount concern lies in the beastmen gaining control of our regions. If too many of us are defeated in a region, the beastmen will gain control of it.

13159 : You want to know about mannequins? Ha ha, there's a word I haven't heard in quite a long time. What would a young adventurer such as yourself want with such an outdated piece?
13160 : Well, I'm not one to judge people on their tastes. Yes, there was a time when we here at the Carpenters' Guild manufactured nearly all of the mannequins in the Kingdom. They were our best sellers.
13161 : Why, that catalog you have there--that was one of many published and printed by us.
13162 : We had so many orders that we had to work twenty-five hours a day to keep up. That is, until the accident...
13163 : Hmph. I can tell by the look on your face that you wish for me to continue. Very well...
13164 : There was to be a grand fashion show held by the Weavers' Guild in Windurst, and they needed a large quantity of mannequins to display all their new clothes and armor.
13165 : It was an enormous undertaking. However, honored to receive such a tremendous order from the Federation, the guildmaster at the time accepted the challenge without hesitation.
13166 : And, as promised, the guild finished all of the beautifully constructed mannequins within the allotted time frame and sent them off to Windurst.
13167 : However, as the shipment was being carried down the Phanauet Channel through Jugner Forest, the ferry was attacked by beastmen. The fiends must have thought the ship was a transport vessel for knights and supplies.
13168 : The few adventurers that accompanied the ship were no match for the enemy, and the ship and her cargo were lost...
13169 : Days later, our guild received a message from Windurst saying that they refused to pay for the stolen mannequins, going as far as citing our negligence in guarding the shipment as justification. Outraged by this blatant breach of contract, our guild continued to demand payment. This feud of sorts lasted for years.
13170 : But that was not the only problem that arose from the accident... Weeks after the attack, the beastmen began throwing the arms, legs, and heads of their prizes over our town walls and into our streets. It was as if they were bragging of their victory.
13171 : Seeing this filled the hearts of the townspeople with fear. Mannequins soon became a symbol of ill fate, and those that remained in shops and guilds were destroyed.
13172 : As a craftsman, it pains me to know that idle superstition has taken such a precedence over fine work. And that is why, as a craftsman, I give my full support to anyone who wishes to recreate such a product. Unfortunately, our guild no longer has any of the materials needed for building a mannequin, nor do I know of one who possesses the skill to construct the pieces necessary.
13173 : Ah, but I do have something that may be of use to you. The goldsmith that constructed the joints for our mannequins left these diagrams. They are of no use to me... Perhaps if a goldsmith were to view them, the plans might give some sort of clue as to their manufacture.
13174 : I can also tell you that in addition to the joints, the following parts were needed to complete a mannequin: %, %, %, %, and %.
13175 : However, you won't find any of those items up on auction. Their sale has been prohibited ever since the accident. If there are any left, they'd be in the hands of the beastmen themselves.

13259 : <Match #> Entry period begins:  Briefing begins:
13260 : I apologize, but your level is too low to participate in an official Brenner match.
13261 : Official matches are scheduled to begin at the following times: Match 1: # Match 2:  Match 3:
13262 : Teleportation to the Isle is free of charge, but a participation fee of # gil is required before each match.
13263 : Travel to the Isle? Yes. Not yet.
13264 : What would you like to know about? Basic rules. Official/private matches. Flammen-Brenner. Flamme. Match score. Petras and quarrying. Sprint. KO. Return.
13265 : The basic rules of Brenner are as follows:
13266 : First, the participants divide into two teams. Each side's camp contains the same number of Flammen-Brenner.
13267 : At the beginning of the match, half of each side's Flammen-Brenner will be ablaze with Flamme, or flame, while the other half will remain unlit.
13268 : Participants can seize a Flamme from the opposing side's Flammen-Brenner and carry it around the Isle.
13269 : The goal is to steal your opponent's Flamme and use them to light your side's Flammen-Brenner.
13270 : The side that succeeds in lighting all of its Flammen-Brenner will be declared the winner after a specified amount of time.
13271 : If neither side is victorious before the match ends, the outcome will be judged based on the score. The match score section of the rulebook contains more information on this subject.
13272 : Brenner is significantly divided into public and private matches. Official matches are held periodically according to level and feature general participation.
13273 : You cannot reserve the Isle when an official match is being held.
13274 : No items are necessary for participation, but a minor fee will be collected. You will be unable to participate if your level is too low.
13275 : The match outcome will be recorded unless the number of participants fails to exceed # members, or if there are fewer than # members in a match where the two sides' numbers differ. In such cases, the game will be considered a training match and will not be recorded.
13276 : Private matches require a reservation, and participation may be limited. The Master of Ceremonies (MC) can freely adjust the rules and control match proceedings.
13277 : LS Liga is a form of private match. You can learn more about LS Liga by speaking to a Marshal.
13278 : A Flammen-Brenner is a device that contains a Flamme (flame). The Flammen-Brenner is covered by a grate that will open after taking a set amount of damage, exposing the Flamme.
13279 : The participants must utilize this chance to seize the Flamme before the grate recloses. Once the grate is closed, the Flammen-Brenner will begin recovering from the damage it has been dealt.
13280 : If you manage to open the opposing team's Flammen-Brenner and capture their Flamme, you should make haste to light one of the Flammen-Brenner on your side.
13281 : After a certain amount of time, the Flamme will burn out and the opposing team's Flammen-Brenner will be relit.
13282 : Also, please note that you cannot quicken your pace using any special abilities while you are in possession of a Flamme.
13283 : In the event that neither side fulfills the conditions for victory, the outcome of the match will be evaluated based on score.
13284 : Ten points are awarded to each side for every lit Flammen-Brenner, while one point is awarded whenever a Flamme is captured, used to light a Flammen-Brenner, or recaptured from an opponent. One point is also awarded for protecting the Flammen-Brenner for a certain period of time.
13285 : Like Ballista, quarry (/quarry) can be used while playing Brenner. Participants may use this ability to dig up Petras and temporary items.
13286 : However, unlike Ballista Petras, Brenner Petras have no effect on the match score. You can trade a Petra to a Pursuivant to recover your HP and MP at no expense to TP.
13287 : Sprint cannot be used while carrying a Petra. Also, please note that the scout ability cannot be used in Brenner.
13288 : Petras will be lost in the event of a KO, but can be carried over from one match to another.
13289 : The sprint (/sprint) ability can be used to increase the player's speed when not in possession of a Flamme or Petras.
13290 : In the event of a KO, you will be returned to your team's camp. However, recovery will take longer the more often you fall in battle.
13291 : In other words, you will receive a penalty if you fall immediately after recovering from KO. In addition, your TP will be reduced to zero and you will lose any Petras in your possession.

13384 : This story finds its beginning almost five hundred years ago... It reaches back to an era considered to be a time of humiliation for the Elvaan.

13520 : Once, long ago, there was a novice goldsmith named Albanus who spent day and night studying the art of bellmaking. He was quite a prodigy, people said.

13523 : At first the bellmaker was puzzled, but soon grew fond of the boy and his appreciation of Albanus's work. And though he himself was still an amateur, he allowed the boy to become his pupil, and proceeded to teach him the ways of smithing.
13524 : However, it turned out that the pupil did more teaching than the master. The boy began telling Albanus how he was to create his bells, and it was not long before the boy's influence was heard in the song that rang forth from the novice goldsmith's workshop.

14939 : Your chocobo is sleeping soundly. You cannot feed it now.
14940 : Your chocobo has run away. You cannot feed it now.
14941 : You cannot feed a chocobo that has not hatched yet.
14942 : It seems like it will have some sort of effect on the chocobo...
14943 : Let me know if you have any questions about chocobo raising.
14944 : What would you like to ask about? The Vana'diel Chocobo Society. Time required. Chocobo attributes. Care schedule. Caring for your chocobo. Feed. Abilities and personality. Retirement. Matchmaking. Calling chocobos in the field. Items. Lost chicks. Nothing.
14945 : Just let me know if you ever get curious!
14946 : The Vana'diel Chocobo Society, or VCS for short, is an international organization designed to train and dispatch chocogirls and chocoguys to stables across Vana'diel.
14947 : They provide courses on practical chocobo riding and the proper ways to care for a chocobo, as well as working to improve the treatment of chocobos from here to Aht Urhgan.
14948 : Anyone can join as long as they love chocobos. The VCS will help you with anything you need.
14949 : Chicks hatch from eggs, grow into young chocobos, and finally mature.
14950 : They grow much faster than people do. Usually it takes about 1 month (Earth time) before you can ride your chocobo.
14951 : The chocobo's traits are determined by the way in which you care for your animal. Without proper planning, you won't be able to raise the type of chocobo that you want.
14952 : But don't worry, because you have us to help! We're all in this together!
14953 : Ask about which attribute? Strength. Endurance. Discernment. Receptivity. Energy. Affection. Satisfaction. Nothing.
14954 : Strength is a term used to describe the chocobo's leg power. The more strength a chocobo has, the faster it will be able to run. Rental chocobos have been raised with an emphasis on this attribute.
14955 : Both strength and endurance are collectively referred to as Physical attributes.
14956 : Endurance is a term used to describe the chocobo's stamina. If your chocobo has high endurance, you will be able to ride it for a long period of time.
14957 : Both strength and endurance are collectively referred to as Physical attributes.
14958 : Discernment is a must for anyone who wants their chocobo to learn new abilities. You may want to consider raising this attribute if you are interested in digging for treasure.
14959 : Both discernment and receptivity are collectively referred to as Mental attributes.
14960 : Receptivity is a term used to describe the chocobo's sensitivity when dealing with others. You can foster receptivity in your chocobo by giving it lots of opportunities to communicate with other chocobos.
14961 : Both discernment and receptivity are collectively referred to as Mental attributes.
14962 : Energy is a term used to describe the amount of power the chocobo needs to stay active for the day. If your chocobo has a lot of energy, care plans are more likely to be successful and you can provide more direct care for your chocobo.
14963 : You can restore your chocobo's energy by feeding it, so remember not to skip out on feeding time after a demanding schedule!
14964 : Affection is the most important attribute of all. Your care schedule will fall flat if you don't show your chocobo proper affection!
14965 : You can raise your chocobo's affection by feeding it greens and caring for it on a regular basis.
14966 : If you really want to raise your chocobo's affection quickly, you can give it %, but I can't recommend doing so unless absolutely necessary.
14967 : Satisfaction is a term used to describe how full or hungry your chocobo is. If your chocobo is full, it will gain a lot of energy before the next day.
14968 : However, when the chocobo is very hungry, its energy will hardly recover at all and its affection will rapidly decrease.
14969 : What would you like to ask about? What is a care schedule? Basic care. Resting. Taking a walk. Listening to music. Exercising alone. Exercising in a group. Interacting with children. Interacting with chocobos. Carrying packages. Exhibiting to the public. Delivering messages. Digging for treasure. Acting in a play. Nothing.
14970 : A care schedule is a series of plans that you set up for your chocobo so that we can take care of it while you are away.
14971 : How you want us to care for your chocobo each day is completely up to you.
14972 : You can register up to four plans at once, each for up to 7 days (Earth time).
14973 : When you come to check on your chocobo, we will give you a report on the results. You should listen closely to the report and use it as reference when deciding on a new schedule.
14974 : With the basic care plan, we will provide the minimum level of care for your chocobo. This plan is the most stable, and your chocobo will probably not experience any sudden changes.
14975 : The basic care plan is good for those who don't want their chocobo's traits to change much or are still unsure of what kind of schedule to choose.
14976 : You can select the basic care plan the moment you start raising your chocobo.
14977 : The rest plan's name speaks for itself. We will give your chocobo a rest in order to restore its energy and cure any status abnormalities.
14978 : However, your chocobo will not be able to eat any food you give it during the plan, because it will be in a deep sleep.
14979 : We can take your chocobo for a walk in town to improve its physical attributes of strength and endurance. However, it will have a negative effect on its mental attributes of discernment and receptivity.
14980 : Listening to music will improve your chocobo's mental attributes of discernment and receptivity. However, it will have a negative effect on its physical attributes of strength and endurance.
14981 : Exercising alone will significantly improve your chocobo's strength. On the other hand, its mental attributes will markedly decrease.
14982 : If the chocobo is strong, this plan is quite effective, but if the chocobo is weak, then you shouldn't push it too hard.
14983 : Exercising with chocobos will build your animal's endurance. On the other hand, its mental attributes will decrease.
14984 : If the chocobo has high endurance, this plan is quite effective, but if the chocobo's endurance is low, then you shouldn't push it too hard.
14985 : Interacting with children helps your chocobo become a more discerning creature by interacting with people.
14986 : However, this plan will have a negative effect on the chocobo's physical attributes, as no strenuous exercise is involved.
14987 : If the chocobo has good discernment, this plan is quite effective, but if the chocobo does not have good discernment, then you shouldn't push it too hard.
14988 : Interacting with other chocobos in the field will improve the chocobo's receptivity by fostering its communication skills.
14989 : But because the focus is on communication and not exercise, this plan will have a negative effect on the chocobo's physical attributes.
14990 : If the chocobo has good receptivity, this plan is quite effective, but if the chocobo does not have good receptivity, then you shouldn't push it too hard.
14991 : You can choose to have your chocobo help deliver packages. Not only will this improve its physical attributes, but you will even receive payment for your services!
14992 : The downside is that your chocobo's mental attributes, energy, and affection will decrease. You must care well for your chocobo, or you might find yourself getting cold treatment.
14993 : You can choose to exhibit your chocobo to the public, which will allow anyone visiting the chocobo stables to take a look at your animal. Being the center of attention will help improve your chocobo's mental attributes.
14994 : The downside is that your chocobo's physical attributes, energy, and affection will decrease. You must care well for your chocobo afterwards. Also, you will receive payment for this service.
14995 : You can choose to have your chocobo deliver official messages for the nation. Not only will this improve its strength, but you will even receive payment for your services!
14996 : However, this plan consumes quite a bit of your chocobo's energy, so you should feed it well to make up for it.
14997 : You can have your chocobo help out VCS finances by digging for treasure. This will also improve the chocobo's discernment.
14998 : The VCS will sell the item and use the money for the organization's benefit, but will provide you with payment for your services.
14999 : However, this plan consumes quite a bit of your chocobo's energy, so you should feed it well to make up for it.
15000 : You can choose to have your chocobo act as an extra in a play to improve its receptivity.
15001 : You will receive payment in accordance with the chocobo's performance. However, this plan consumes quite a bit of your chocobo's energy, so you should feed it well to make up for it.
15002 : What would you like to ask about? A general explanation. Watching over your chocobo. Telling a story. Scolding. Competing. Taking a walk. Nothing.
15003 : In addition to setting the chocobo's schedule, you can also care directly for your chocobo whenever you like.
15004 : Caring for your chocobo will increase its affection for you.
15005 : On the other hand, a chocobo that receives too much care will lose energy more rapidly when engaging in activities. If you do nothing but care for your chocobo, it will become fatigued.
15006 : However, not caring enough for your chocobo will have a negative effect on your relationship, so it is important to find a balance.
15007 : You can watch over your chocobo whenever you like.
15008 : Your fond gaze can communicate even more than a touch and will not have a very tiring effect on the animal.
15009 : You can tell the chocobo a story you know. This will foster the animal's sensibilities.
15010 : I've heard that by listening to the story, the chocobo might even realize it has powers it never noticed before. (I've never seen it happen before, though...)
15011 : Sometimes your chocobo might start acting spoiled or refuse to do anything but sleep. In such times, you will need to firmly scold it.
15012 : This will shame the animal and have an effect on its receptivity.
15013 : Competing against other chocobos will cultivate your animal's ambitious spirit and is highly effective for bored chocobos.
15014 : You can take your chocobo out for a walk in the field. You will be able to choose more destinations as your chocobo grows.
15015 : I like to take the chocobo out often, too, but I'm sure it prefers going out with you.
15016 : Leaving the stables every once in a while allows your chocobo to experience new sights and sounds. Maybe you'll even discover something new together!
15017 : What would you like to know about? Why feeding is important. Vegetables. Wildgrasses. Carrots. Worms. Medicines. Pastes. Nothing.
15018 : Chocobos digest feed quickly, so they are often hungry.
15019 : However, they also restore energy at a rapid pace. If you do not feed your chocobo properly, it will be unable to restore enough energy.
15020 : The chocobo stables will provide your chocobo with the minimum amount of feed required for the animal to survive, but you need to provide more in order to ensure its healthy growth.
15021 : At the same time, feeding your chocobo too much can result in a stomachache. Remember to strike a balance with both the variety and quantity of feed you give to your animal!
15022 : Some types of feed have special effects, so it is important not to neglect your chocobo's diet if you want to raise a good chocobo.
15023 : There are different methods of acquiring these special types of feed, so be on the lookout for them!
15024 : Just trade the feed to an advanced chocobo trainer, and they will give it to your chocobo.
15025 : This is the standard variety of chocobo feed, among which % are most popular.
15026 : Chocobos also seem to enjoy % and %.
15027 : These greens are the most effective in satisfying a chocobo's hunger. Chocobos also enjoy the taste, which raises affection for their owner.
15028 : Wildgrasses are a type of medicinal herb. They do not taste very good, but are highly effective at curing status abnormalities.
15029 : %, for example, works well on wounds. So although they look similar to %, the effects are different.
15030 : In addition, % is effective for illness, and % for a stomachache. It's a good idea to remember which herb to use in each situation.
15031 : Carrots are high in nutrition, and will have an effect on the chocobo's strength and discernment.
15032 : %, for example, affect the chocobo's physical attributes, and % are good for its mental attributes. % are in a category of their own.
15033 : Remember, though, that the results are very slight, and keeping a good care schedule is a far more efficient way to alter your chocobo's attributes.
15034 : Using worms as feed can have a variety of effects. They might look disgusting, but their effectiveness is not to be ignored!
15035 : For example, % will dramatically increase your chocobo's affection, and % will restore its energy.
15036 : But watch out for the side effects... Give the chocobo a worm at the wrong time, and all your effort could come to nothing...
15037 : The most curious of all the worms is the %. At first it may not seem to have any effect, but looks are deceiving...
15038 : Medicines can cure a chocobo in the blink of an eye.
15039 : % will restore your chocobo's energy in full, making it easier to care for and ensuring that the care schedule goes smoothly.
15040 : % are effective for most status abnormalities, restoring instant health to your chocobo. Of course, you still need to continue caring for your chocobo so it can fully recover.
15041 : A potion can also help fill a chocobo's stomach, so they can be useful when you are short on feed.
15042 : Feed can be ground into paste for chicks to eat.
15043 : You can make paste yourself with some cooking skill. If you don't have enough cooking skill yourself, then you might want to ask a friend to make some for you.
15044 : Chicks can also eat regular feed, though.
15045 : Which would you like to ask about? Abilities. Temperament. Weather preferences. Nothing.
15046 : Your chocobo may learn useful abilities during the course of its life at the stables.
15047 : For example, Auto-Regen will increase the rate at which your chocobo restores energy. Such an ability is sure to come in handy in a variety of situations.
15048 : Your chocobo learns abilities by listening to your words, so if you know of any story that you think might interest the animal, you should tell it often.
15049 : But remember, your chocobo can't learn all of the abilities there are. It can only learn two...or at least, that's what I read.
15050 : The chocobo's temperament is determined when it is just a chick. Its temperament and attributes are somehow related, but I'm not really sure how.
15051 : Chocobos generally like sunny days, but they could grow to like other kinds of weather depending on how they are raised.
15052 : Chocobos pay attention to the air outside when they go on walks, and grow to prefer that type of weather because of the memories.
15053 : Make the animal's schedule around its preferred weather days, and plans are more likely to succeed. However, if the chocobo has a favored type of weather, it also dislikes certain conditions, creating a weak point to watch for.
15054 : You can choose to retire your chocobo at any time after it has fully matured.
15055 : After retirement, the VCS will take up caring for the chocobo where you left off, so you need not worry about its welfare.
15056 : When your chocobo retires, you will receive %. Be sure not to lose it.
15057 : You can use the % to register your chocobo to call in the field or for matchmaking purposes after retirement. All you need to do is trade it to a VCS member.
15058 : The empty stall created after your animal retires can be used for raising other chocobos, so if you happen to come across another egg, you can bring it here to start all over again!
15059 : When your chocobo is mature enough, you can breed it with another chocobo. If the chocobo lays an egg, the chick will inherit the traits of its parents.
15060 : You will need % and % if you want to breed your chocobo. Apparently, you also need some kind of ticket that they sell at the stables in Upper Jeuno.
15061 : You can ask one of the VCS members to issue you a chococard, or if your chocobo is already retired, just trade them %.
15062 : I don't really know that much about it, but you should probably try matching your chocobo up with several different animals and seeing what the results are.
15063 : When your chocobo is mature enough, you can call it in the field using %.
15064 : You need to let a member of the VCS know which chocobo you want to respond to your call, because they must choose a saddle that fits your chocobo's attributes.
15065 : That also means that when your chocobo's attributes change or it learns a new ability, you should probably let the VCS member know, too.
15066 : When you want to register a retired chocobo to respond to your call in the field, trade % to a VCS member.
15067 : Also, the %'s power will grow weak after you've used it several times.
15068 : If this happens, just trade it to a VCS member and they will give you a new one for a fee.
15069 : What would you like to ask about? %. Chococards. %. Nothing.
15070 : % proves that you are your chocobo's caretaker.
15071 : With this card, you can register a retired chocobo to respond to your call in the field or get a chococard for matchmaking.
15072 : If you lose it, you won't be able to get another one, so keep it in a safe place!
15073 : You can use % to call your chocobo in the field to use as a mount.
15074 : The more you use it, the weaker it will get, so eventually you will need to exchange it to a VCS member for a new one.
15075 : Only people who have been approved by the VCS President can get %, so good luck with that...
15076 : Chococards are documents that contain all the details about a chocobo's attributes and condition. They are divided into two types--one for each gender.
15077 : If you trade one to the person who's in charge of matchmaking, he'll introduce your animal to another chocobo.
15078 : Chococards contain information on the chocobo's attributes and condition at the time the card is issued, so be sure to get a new card before using this service or the match will be arranged based on out-of-date information.
15079 : If you want a chococard for a retired chocobo, then you must trade % to a VCS member.

16200 : Why not!? Our original plan was to establish locations across Vana'diel where people could test their birds' skills.
16201 : We felt that this would help us maintain breeder motivation, which in turn would ensure healthier, happier chocobos. A win-win situation, as we like to call it in the business.
16202 : However, as rumors of these new facilities began to leak out into the world, people began speculating about the possibility of officially sanctioned chocobo races...
16203 : The VCS could not ignore the voice of the masses, and it was not long before a meeting was held, a vote was taken, and the CRA was formed.

16206 : First of all, your chocobo must be fully grown. It doesn't matter if you are still tending to it, or if it has been sent to pasture, as long as it is large enough to ride.
16207 : Next, you must bring me either % or %. This is all I will require. There are no hidden fees.
16208 : As your chocobo develops, be sure to re-register it. This will ensure that your steed is provided with the equipment that most suits its current condition.
16209 : Finally, you may only register one chocobo at a time, but are free to register a new bird whenever you wish. You need only speak with me to make any necessary changes.
16210 : Once you have registered your chocobo and entered it in a competition, the CRA will proceed in assigning it a licensed jockey.
16211 : Before each race you will be given the opportunity to give the jockey specific orders on his or her riding style.
16212 : In addition to these orders, you can also provide the jockey with items to use while riding, as well as equipment to improve your chocobo's performance.
16213 : Before a race, you can also check the strengths and weaknesses of the other participating chocobos. It is recommended that you use this data when deciding on what orders to give, or which items to equip.
16214 : Depending on your chocobo's performance in select CRA-sanctioned races, you may or may not receive a prize consisting of VCS-mint chocobucks.
16215 : Chocobucks can be used to purchase items, as well as upgrade your mount. Chocobucks are also required to participate in official races.
16216 : Currently, players can earn up to, but no more than, 1000 chocobucks. However, this may change without notice.
16217 : There are two main types of races.
16218 : The first type is called an official race. To participate in one of these, you will require chocobucks.
16219 : Placing in an official race will earn you gil. The more races you complete, the more respected you will become in the breeder community.
16220 : You may also take part in an official race as often as needed to complete the specified objectives.
16221 : However, after some of the more grueling races, you may be required to wait before entering the next. This is to give your chocobo, as well as the others, an opportunity to rest before running again.
16222 : The second type of race is called a free run. Unlike the official races, these can be run at any time, regardless of the results of a previous match.
16223 : You must pay a fee in gil to participate in free runs, but you will have the opportunity to earn chocobucks depending on your chocobo's performance. You can join as many free runs as you wish in a single day (Earth time), but extra fees may be required for each additional race. (Stable hands have to make a living, too!)
16224 : The CRA is split up into three racing teams representing Bastok, Windurst, and San d'Oria.
16225 : Each team has its own skilled jockeys, and offers unique services that cannot be obtained at the other two.
16226 : Breeders are allowed to register with any team they like, and may change their affiliation at any time.
16227 : In the event that you wish to leave a racing team, all official race results, as well as earned chocobucks, will be saved.
16228 : You never have to worry that your past accomplishments may be deleted and lost forever. You only need rejoin the team to restore all your old data.
16229 : Anyway, there is no harm in visiting all three racing teams to find which one suits you best (though I know you'll choose this one).
16230 : Ah, it says here that you are a member of the [San d'Oria/Bastok/Windurst] racing team.
16231 : Have you come today to change your affiliation?
16232 : Remember, you will not be able to use any chocobucks earned in [San d'Oria/Bastok/Windurst] here, and you will also lose any Solo Victory Points that you may have. Are you sure you want to go through with this?

16261 : Use this race to learn the ropes. Try not to worry too much about the other chocobos, and concentrate on discovering your bird's strengths and weaknesses.
16262 : Novice Race II Chocobos: 6 Objective: Place 3rd or higher

16264 : Novice Race III Chocobos: 8 Objective: Place 3rd or higher

16406 : A standard model, the lauan saddle will stabilize your chocobo's stride.
16407 : A standard model, the ash saddle will stabilize your chocobo's stride. It also increases your mount's endurance.
16408 : A standard model, the elm saddle will stabilize your chocobo's stride. It also increases your mount's endurance.
16409 : A bit on the hefty side, the brass saddle can be somewhat taxing on a chocobo's endurance. It compensates for this, however, by increasing the bird's strength.
16410 : A bit on the hefty side, the silver saddle can be somewhat taxing on a chocobo's endurance. It compensates for this, however, by increasing the bird's strength.
16411 : A bit on the hefty side, the mythril saddle can be somewhat taxing on a chocobo's endurance. It compensates for this, however, by increasing the bird's strength.
16412 : This lightweight grass saddle can create a marked improvement in physical performance. However, a chocobo will require some degree of discernment to reap its benefits.
16413 : This lightweight cotton saddle can create a marked improvement in physical performance. However, a chocobo will require some degree of discernment to reap its benefits.
16414 : This lightweight linen saddle can create a marked improvement in physical performance. However, a chocobo will require some degree of discernment to reap its benefits.
16415 : Crafted from the finest rabbit hide, this saddle can improve physical performance, but only for chocobos with at least moderate receptivity.
16416 : Crafted from the finest sheep leather, this saddle can improve physical performance, but only for chocobos with at least moderate receptivity.
16417 : Crafted from the finest buffalo leather, this saddle can improve physical performance, but only for chocobos with at least moderate receptivity.

16487 : Current Standings Three-nation deadlock!
16488 : Last Week's Standings Team San d'Oria: # Team Bastok: # Team Windurst: #
16489 : Helping your team into first will give you certain advantages over your rivals! That should give you something to strive for!
16490 : What would you like to know about? The promenade. Chocobet centers. The grandstand. Portals. Guides. Nothing for now.
16491 : Shops, as well as attendants to assist you in siging up your chocobo for a race, are located on the promenade.
16492 : It can be found just south of here.
16493 : The promenade itself is split into eastern and western halves, both of which house all of the same facilities. Be sure to stop by and have a look when you get a chance.
16494 : Attendants at the chocobet centers are there to assist you with acquiring %, as well as collecting your winnings.
16495 : There are a total of five centers readily available for your convenience, each of which are located near the transportation portals. There are two to the east and west of here, and one just to the north.
16496 : All chocobet centers are capable of providing the same services.
16497 : The grandstand faces the racetrack itself, and allows spectators to sit and enjoy the races in comfort.
16498 : To get there, just follow the red carpet all the way through the betting area. You can't miss it.
16499 : The standard admission fee is # gil. Patrons who possess % may enter free of charge.
16500 : % will be provided anytime you purchase % or sign up for a race.
16501 : Your % will become invalid as soon as you leave the grandstand. Reentry will require you to pay an additional admission fee.
16502 : This racetrack is equipped with portals to transport our patrons to any of the three nations, as well as Jeuno and Al Zahbi.
16503 : As you can see, we are regularly visited by a multitude of race fans, breeders, and jockeys from every realm imaginable. We have therefore relegated each portal to a single destination in an attempt to avoid congestion.
16504 : For the same reasons, we ask that visitors refrain from setting up bazaars while here. Violators of this rule will be severely punished. Your cooperation is appreciated.
16505 : Guides can be found throughout the premises waiting to assist you.
16506 : They can help by transporting you to the location of your choice.
16507 : This service is provided free of charge, so please don't hesitate to make use of it.
16508 : What would you like to know about? Racing teams. Race rules. Race types. Victory points. Race Progression. That's about it.
16509 : A race chocobo's owner or jockey may join one of the three racing teams by registering at the appropriate VCS branch.
16510 : Each nation's Team Victory Points are the sum total of all of its members' Solo Victory Points. The Team Victory Point totals are then used to determine the overall weekly standings.
16511 : In order to race your chocobo here, we ask that you please affiliate yourself first with one of the three teams.
16512 : For details, please check with your local CRA racing center.
16513 : The races held here are almost identical to the official and private races held at the other racetracks.
16514 : What distinguishes our races is the fact that victories here qualify you to collect larger cash purses, as well as Victory Points.
16515 : Eligibility to participate in the higher-level races will require a certain number of Solo Victory Points.
16516 : Depending on a team's weekly standings, its members may suffer certain eligibility restrictions. At the same time, they may also be privy to certain benefits.
16517 : The teams in second and third place will have the advantage of being allowed more entry positions in any given race, while those of the leading team are restricted.
16518 : The leading team will, however, be granted the privilege of selecting higher-quality saddles for their race chocobos.
16519 : The CRA reserves the right to impose a handicap system when it is determined that the gap in skill between chocobos is simply too great to make for a fair race.
16520 : In such an event, the less endowed of the chocobos will be granted certain enhancing effects, such as Haste or Refresh.
16521 : Whether handicaps will be enforced or not will be determined after signups are complete. Make sure to keep an eye on your chocobo's settings.
16522 : Each race title will include a code, such as C4. This code is the race grade.
16523 : For example, a C4 Chocobo Race would indicate a typical grade 4 race.
16524 : We have four race grades, ranging from C4 to C1. The lower the number, the higher the grade. This, of course, means larger entry fees, but also more prize money.
16525 : No matter which race you enter, upon completion you will be prevented from joining any other races for a period of 20 hours (Earth time). Higher-grade races carry larger purses, so most racers like to use their opportunities to go after those.
16526 : Solo Victory Points will be awarded to you every race, depending on how well you finish.
16527 : As your Solo Victory Points accumulate, your chocobo will be able to gain entry to high-grade races.
16528 : Should a racer return to the circuit after an absence of four weeks or more, the CRA will be forced to deduct a number of Solo Victory Points.
16529 : Only on the rarest of occasions will such penalties be imposed. However, there are some races in which you will be unable to participate if you do not have a certain amount of Solo Victory Points in your possession.
16530 : Also, obtaining Solo Victory Points will also grant your nation Team Victory Points.
16531 : The three teams are in constant competition with one another, and a weekly ranking system is in place based on Team Victory Point totals.
16532 : As a team climbs up in rank, certain benefits will follow. You may see new items available for purchase with chocobucks, preferential treatment at the races, and so on.
16533 : Keep in mind that should you change your team affiliation, you will be forced to forfeit any accumulated Solo Victory Points.
16534 : We have a total of four races that run in succession.
16535 : Each race has its own dedicated signup window. Here there will be four attendants ready to serve all your racing needs.
16536 : Even if the race registration at one window closes, registration for the next race will begin immediately at the neighboring window.
16537 : Races will be held one after the other, so you'll have plenty of chances to watch and bet. Sit back, relax, and enjoy!
16538 : What would you like to hear more about? Race preparations. Signup procedure. Collecting winnings. Signing up for another race. I'm fine, thanks.
16539 : There are a few facts that you should know before running in a race.
16540 : First of all, you absolutely must be affiliated with one of the three official racing teams. These, as you may already know, are San d'Oria, Bastok, and Windurst.
16541 : Secondly, it is required that your bird be registered as a race chocobo, for obvious reasons. No race chocobo, no race.
16542 : Thirdly, you will be responsible for providing your own items to be used during the race. The CRA leaves this to the racer's discretion...
16543 : All of these services can be provided at any racing center, but to facilitate the registration process it is recommended that you conduct all such affairs at the appropriate branch.
16544 : A racing fee is necessary to gain entry into a chocobo race. The racing center will inform you of the cost, so please be sure to pay when signing up for a race.
16545 : Also, when signing up to race, you will be able to choose a saddle, as well as the lane in which your chocobo will race.
16546 : There are multifarious saddles at the rider's disposal, each of which will affect your chocobo's conditioning. In addition, the types of saddles available will change depending on your team's current ranking.
16547 : There are a total of eight lanes, but general conditions for all of them are the same. Feel free to race in the lane of your choice.
16548 : Setting these options will complete the signup process. You will then be given %, which you will need to exchange later to collect any winnings.
16549 : In the event that you should lose or misplace your %, you will be unable to collect any prize money, chocobucks, or Victory Points that you may be entitled to. I cannot stress enough how important it is to hold on to it.
16550 : The races can be viewed from our grandstand area. Take a seat and cheer on your bird!
16551 : You will be eligible for prize money if your chocobo places either first, second, or third.
16552 : To collect, simply hand in the % you received during race signup at any signup center.
16553 : The amount of gil, chocobucks, and Victory Points you qualify to receive will be based upon your bird's placement.
16554 : You will lose the right to collect your winnings from a race exactly one week after that race has ended.
16555 : After participating in a race, your chocobo will be unable to join any other races for a period of 20 hours (Earth time).
16556 : This pertains only to races held here, and will not affect your eligibility for races held at any other racetracks.
16557 : We have implemented these restrictions here as to allow the greatest number of participants' entry into our races. Your patience and understanding are appreciated.
16558 : What would you like to ask? What is chocobetting? How do I bet? What are odds? When do I bet? How do I collect winnings? Nothing.
16559 : Chocobetting is a form of entertainment where bettors attempt to pick the two birds that will finish first and second in a race.
16560 : To make it a bit more interesting, the bettor can then wager on their picks in increments of 100 gil.
16561 : Should lady luck smile upon you and your picks hit, you can win prize money, the amount of which is determined by the odds for that race.
16562 : For example, let's say that you were to bet ten quills (1000 gil) on Entries No. 5 and No. 7.
16563 : And let's say that the toteboard showed the odds for the race at 110 gil. If your picks were to finish as the top two birds, you would be eligible to collect 1100 gil in winnings, for a total profit of 100 gil.
16564 : Of course, it goes without saying that should your picks not have the fortune of finishing in the top two places, you will receive absolutely no gil.
16565 : The gambler's fallacy is our mantra here at the racetrack! Remember, you are special! Let it ride!
16566 : To place a chocobet, you must obtain % from the chocobet center.
16567 : For any single %, a bettor may purchase up to 999 quills. Each quill costs 100 gil.
16568 : We highly recommend that you obtain information on the chocobos you will be betting on before purchasing your ticket. It is always good to know where your money is going.
16569 : Odds determine how much gil you will receive in winnings per quill on your chocobet ticket.
16570 : Winnings are calculated by taking the total monetary sum of all bets for any given pairing. For example, should ten bettors each place the same 100-quill (10,000 gil) chocobet, the total used to determine the winnings would be 100,000 gil.
16571 : It goes without saying that not all bettors will be winners. The money from losing bets is used to pay off the winners.
16572 : What this means is that if you place a bet on an unseemly chocobo pairing, or pick two birds without much money riding on them, and are fortunate enough to win, you can make quite a tidy sum.
16573 : Toteboards display the odds at both the chocobet center as well as the grandstand. Toteboards have eight columns with the number on top of each column representing one chocobo, and the number to the left of each column representing another. If your bet is for chocobos No. 2 and No. 5, check the #2 column to see how much a 2-5 bet will pay per quill.
16574 : The odds are constantly changing right up until the race begins. If the number of bets on a popular chocobo pairing keeps increasing, then consequently the odds will go down.
16575 : Even if you place a large bet early on, the odds may still change as time passes. So take your time and consider carefully.
16576 : Chocobets can be placed as soon as the signup period for a race has ended. The betting window will close several minutes before the race begins.
16577 : Make sure to get your bet in on time. Even if you are in the middle of placing a bet, it will be cancelled if you exceed the allowed time window by even a single second.
16578 : Once the race is finished, you can exchange your % at any chocobet center to collect your winnings.
16579 : Without % you will be unable to collect your winnings, so make sure not to lose it.
16580 : % is valid for up to one week (Earth time) after completion of the race for which it was purchased.
16581 : Should one week pass, we will be unable to accept the ticket, so it is always best to cash out as soon as possible.

16636 : Greetings, and welcome to the Chocobo Racing Association's (CRA) [San d'Oria/Bastok/Windurst] branch. This service area is here to accommodate our more experienced and accomplished racers.
16637 : I am truly sorry [sir/ma'am], but we are unable to service your request here. This service area only caters to [San d'Orian/Bastokan/Windurstian] CRA Classic winners.
16638 : Registration for such an event can be carried out at the service areas for beginning and intermediate racers. Please speak to the attendants there for further assistance.
16639 : The organizing attendants in each location are as follows: [Southern San d'Oria: Alangriche/Bastok Mines: Jazgeh/Windurst Waters: Turumi-Byrumi] [Northern San d'Oria: Monteverle/Bastok Markets: Galienne/Windurst Port: Lhimo Keanyohn] [Port San d'Oria: Ramiene/Port Bastok: Salvador/Windurst Woods: Rungaga].
16640 : For beginning and intermediate races, you'll want to speak with [Alangriche/Jazgeh/Rungaga].
16641 : My apologies, [sir/ma'am], but it appears that you have yet to conduct all of the necessary processing at the service area for beginning and intermediate racers. Please speak to the attendants there for further assistance.
16642 : My apologies, [sir/ma'am], but it appears that you have yet to conduct all of the necessary processing at the service area for advanced and veteran racers. Please speak to the attendants there for further assistance.
16643 : Which would you like to hear about? CRA rationale behind veteran races. How do I register for a race? How do I prepare for a race? What are chocobucks? What kinds of races are there? What are racing teams? What about race opponents? Quit. Return.
16644 : With the establishment of the Chocobo Circuit and the introduction of chocobo races, the hidden talents of a number of chocobos across Vana'diel finally had a venue in which to come to fruition.
16645 : As the next step, the CRA recognized these rare and valuable talents, and developed a new, special kind of race to showcase them even more than before!
16646 : The Monster Races!
16647 : Without the interference of jockeys, breeders can now pit their chocobos head-to-head against a number of monster species in brutal, raw, no-holds-barred racing!
16648 : Even some of the CRA's very own best and brightest chocobos will be entering into these races geared specifically to our veteran clientele. What more thrilling way to spend a day at the races than to see Vana'diel's most elite chocobos competing against its most fiendish monsters!?
16649 : First of all, your chocobo must be fully grown. It doesn't matter if you are still tending to it, or if it has been sent to pasture, as long as it is large enough to ride.
16650 : Next, you must bring me either % or %. This is all I will require. There are no hidden fees.
16651 : As your chocobo develops, be sure to re-register it. This will ensure that your steed is provided with the equipment that most suits its current condition.
16652 : Finally, you may only register one chocobo at a time, but are free to register a new bird whenever you wish. You need only speak with me to make any necessary changes.
16653 : Since these races are geared towards our more veteran racers and will not make use of jockeys, all in-race conduct is based solely on the chocobos themselves. The CRA wants these races to be as pure as possible!
16654 : The same philosophy applies to the usage of items as well. Simply preset the items you wish for your chocobo to have at its disposal. It will use them as it sees fit based on real-time assessment of racing conditions.
16655 : Many breeders are distressed by these rules, but we assure you there is no need for concern. If your chocobo has progressed far enough in the Chocobo Circuit to even be participating in the Monster Races, it is a given that it has enough know-how to use its items wisely. Have faith in your bird.
16656 : Also, as with other races in the past, you will be able to check on the strengths and weaknesses of your opponents at this service area. Many breeders like to use this information for developing their race strategies, and we encourage you to do the same.
16657 : Depending on your chocobo's performance in select CRA-sanctioned races, you may or may not receive a prize consisting of VCS-mint chocobucks.
16658 : Chocobucks can be used to purchase items, as well as upgrade your mount. Chocobucks are also required to participate in official races.
16659 : Currently, players can earn up to, but no more than, 1000 chocobucks. However, this may change without notice.
16660 : There are two main types of races.
16661 : The first type is called an official race. To participate in one of these, you will require chocobucks.
16662 : Placing in an official race will earn you gil. The more races you complete, the more respected you will become in the breeder community.
16663 : You may also take part in an official race as often as needed to complete the specified objectives.
16664 : However, after some of the more grueling races, you may be required to wait before entering the next. This is to give your chocobo, as well as the others, an opportunity to rest before running again.
16665 : The second type of race is called a free run. Unlike the official races, these can be run at any time, regardless of the results of a previous match. In addition, you will have the opportunity to earn chocobucks depending on your chocobo's performance.
16666 : You are not able to sign up for free runs at this location. To do so, please visit the appropriate service area for beginning and intermediate racers. Thank you for your understanding.
16667 : The CRA is split up into three racing teams representing Bastok, Windurst, and San d'Oria.
16668 : Each team has its own skilled jockeys, and offers unique services that cannot be obtained at the other two.
16669 : Breeders are allowed to register with any team they like, and may change their affiliation at any time.
16670 : In the event that you wish to leave a racing team, all official race results, as well as earned chocobucks, will be saved.
16671 : You never have to worry that your past accomplishments may be deleted and lost forever. You only need rejoin the team to restore all your old data.
16672 : Anyway, there is no harm in visiting all three racing teams to find which one suits you best (though I know you'll choose this one).
16673 : Your opponents in the official monster races will be any of a host of beasts reared and trained by racing aficionado and announcer extraordinaire, Markovich.
16674 : We ensure all participating breeders that these monsters are in no way enhanced or engineered for racing excellence. The CRA has been adamant about maintaining race participants to as close to their natural state of being as possible.
16675 : Though each variety of monster does in fact possess characteristic abilities and traits. And they have undergone extensive training to optimize their use of these in races.
16676 : As with the chocobos, however, the monsters will be absent jockeys of any kind. It is possible, and expected, that they will often unleash their wild, animalistic instincts on the racetrack. Consider yourself warned.
16677 : In the spirit of drawing crowds, the CRA has also elected to place some of their finest birds on the racing roster as well. Breeders can also expect to see other superior-class chocobos taking part. It's going to take a lot more than just speed and endurance to win these races!
16678 : Finally, in the absence of jockeys, finish-line sensors will be employed. These devices will be attached to the contestants' ankles, or in the absence of ankles, some other such appropriate place.
16679 : Dueler's Race Participants: 2 Objective: Place 1st
16680 : And now, Markovich's undeniably unorthodox, and arguably downright unethical, monster race is about to begin!
16681 : Survival Race Participants: 8 Objective: Place 1st
16682 : Following such a fine showing in the Dueler's Race, the next contest is about to start! Who will be the last beast standing?
16683 : Deadly Race Participants: 8 Objective: Place 1st
16684 : Warning! The next race contains monsters of unprecedented nastiness. Enter at your own risk! The name says it all!
16685 : Mystery Race Participants: 4 chocobos & 4 ??? Objective: Place 1st
16686 : What's this? We've been asked to pass along yet another challenge, this time from an anonymous source! I'm not altogether clear on what is about to transpire...
16687 : Lethal Race Participants: 8 Objective: Place 1st
16688 : The games are over, ladies and gentlemen. Markovich is laying it all on the table. Here come his most ferocious beasts to date!
16689 : Dream Race Participants: 8 Objective: Place 1st
16690 : This is the moment you've all been waiting for. The CRA has brought its racing elite out from the stables! The treacherous offroad track is fraught with perils! And an absolutely awe-inspiring trophy is ready for the winner! Bragging rights for life are on the line!
16691 : Which race would you like to rerun? Dueler's Race. Survival Race. Deadly Race. Mystery Race. Lethal Race. Dream Race. ------ ------ Quit. Return.

16698 : Using % mid-race will temporarily boosting the speed of all participants.
16699 : Using % mid-race will temporarily restore the stamina of all participants.
16700 : Using % mid-race will result in your chocobo temporarily gaining immunity to effects caused by items.
16701 : Using % mid-race will result in significantly reducing the speed of a single target.
16702 : Using % mid-race will result in significantly reducing the stamina of a single target.
16703 : Using % mid-race will result in temporarily reducing the speed of all opponents within a given area.
16704 : Using % mid-race will result in temporarily reducing the discernment of all opponents within a given area.
16705 : Using % mid-race will result in temporarily cause the weather conditions to become clear.
16706 : Using % mid-race will result in temporarily cause the weather conditions to become rainy.
16707 : % is a type of gear which can only be equipped during a race. It grants its wearer a slight increase in strength.

16709 : % is a type of gear which can only be equipped during a race. It grants its wearer a slight increase in discernment.
16710 : % is a type of gear which can only be equipped during a race. It grants its wearer a slight increase in receptivity.

17144 : Read which chapter? 1. The Heart of Venture Roll. 2. Rules of the Roll. 3. Putting the Book Down.
17145 : Venture roll is a competitive game played with dice similar to those used by corsairs. The objective is to roll until your cumulative total comes as close to 11 as possible without going over.
17146 : Until you reach or go over 11, you may continue rolling (doubling up) as many times as the table time limit allows (# [minute/minutes], Earth time).
17147 : In addition to doubling up, you may also decline to roll the dice and stay with your current total (hold fast).
17148 : If your total ever goes over 11, you will automatically lose the game, regardless of the totals of other players. Knowing the right time to hold fast is one of the keys to staying in the match.
17149 : Once all the players have held fast, the game is over and the results are announced. The player closest to 11 is declared the winner and receives all the gil in the pot (the original participation fees of all the players).
17150 : Objective: Roll a six-sided die as many times as necessary to achieve a total as close to 11 as possible. You lose the instant your total exceeds 11.
17151 : If two or more players are the closest to 11 at the end of a match, the game is considered a draw and all participation fees are repaid in full.
17152 : Once the game has started, fees will not be refunded for any reason unless the match results in a draw.

17899 : Research into the composition of the cinder produced as a side effect of synergy just might lead to the next breakthrough in our field. Provide us with samples for analysis, and we will gladly reward your contributions.
