17904 : Excellent! And this is yours. May it serve you well!
17905 : You transferred # Pz of cinder to the synergy engineer. # Pz [remains/remain] in your possession.
17906 : Ask about what? Nothing. Synergy furnaces. Synergy overview. Synergy procedure. Synergy recipes. Fewell replenishment. Materials for sale. Synergy techniques. Trading cinder.
17907 : The synergy furnaces you see around town are provided as a public service by the Bastokan Institute of Synergy Research, to ensure that no synergist is ever far away from the tools of their trade.
17908 : The synergist must provide his or her own %, as well as any materials to be used in the synergy process. Provided those conditions are met, synergy furnaces may be used free of charge.
17909 : Needless to say, only one party may operate any given furnace at once.
17910 : Fortunately, there are multiple furnaces installed throughout town. If the furnace before you is already in use, please seek out an unused one elsewhere, or wait patiently for your turn.
17911 : You may think of synergy as an evolved form of synthesis. It is a discipline full of heretofore unimagined possibilities, but one which demands consummate skill from its practitioners.
17912 : Like synthesis, synergy involves combining materials according to a prescribed recipe to yield oft-spectacular results. The rub is that each synergy recipe also dictates a certain elemental balance that must be achieved for the procedure to be successful.
17913 : This balance is achieved through skillful infusion of combustible elemental crystals that we synergists call fewell. To begin the synergy process, you'll have to feed the furnace with fewell and get those flames burning!
17914 : As a general rule, the more complex the recipe, the more fewell it will require. Take care to check your stock before you fire up the furnace, lest you find its flames guttering out at a crucial moment.
17915 : With the belly of the furnace roaring up a storm, it's time to toss in your materials and start synergizing! Keep a close eye on the balance of elements and deploy fewell as necessary. Approach the prescribed elemental balance, and your item will take form, allowing you to remove it from the furnace.
17916 : The closer you are to the ideal elemental balance, the higher the quality of your finished product will be. In synergy, it pays to be a perfectionist!
17917 : But be forewarned: these furnaces can only sustain the elemental maelstrom swirling and storming inside them for so long.
17918 : If the furnace's durability should fail, the synergy process will be interrupted, and you will be forced to start anew.
17919 : Take heart, though, as any materials inside your % will remain intact. You may retrieve them or attempt the synergy process again as you see fit.
17920 : Any fewell consumed in the failed synergy attempt, on the other hand, will be permanently lost.
17921 : Synergists must also be wary of debris buildup, an unavoidable side effect of the volatile elemental reactions that take place within the synergy furnace.
17922 : Should too much debris be allowed to accumulate, the contents of the furnace will become unstable, potentially leading to unpleasant explosions and eruptions. Such accidents pose considerable risk to the synergy attempt in progress, as well as the physical well-being of the synergist, so be sure to exercise due caution!
17923 : You may be asking yourself, Why, how in the name of Hildolf am I going to oversee all of these complicated procedures and variables by myself?
17924 : Here's the good news: you don't have to! For you see, synergy furnaces are designed for use by multiple operators.
17925 : The more complex the recipe, the greater level of skill and hands-on manipulation it will demand. At such times, it would be in your best interest to seek out like-minded synergists and take on the challenge together.
17926 : Finally, it would be remiss of me not to make mention of %, the curious substance whose properties are only now--with the emergence of synergy--becoming known to us.
17927 : Though there is much yet to be learned, our research has revealed that % may be used to bolster your equipment, if attached in a proper manner.
17928 : Mind you, % is not easy to come by, and I can offer no clues as to where or how to obtain it. Should you be fortunate enough to come across some in your travels, however, I encourage you to explore its potential.
17929 : Synergy is not a discipline for the faint of heart or mind, but with dedication and cooperation, there are great rewards to be reaped. May your career as a synergist prove fruitful!
17930 : First, you'll be wanting to check your fewell supply. You may do so by speaking with a synergy engineer such as myself, or by examining a synergy furnace.
17931 : You'll be needing at least one unit of fewell for each element dictated by your recipe. Without this, even the most skilled synergist cannot hope to succeed.
17932 : Should your fewell supply be in order, it's time to proceed with the synergy. If you are using one of these public synergy furnaces here, you'll need to examine it and lay claim to its use.
17933 : You may then deposit your ingredients. Should they correspond to a proper recipe, the synergy furnace will fire up automatically. Note that as a safety precaution, the furnace will not activate if the recipe is beyond your level of synergy skill.
17934 : From here, it becomes a race against the clock! Through skilled operation of the synergy furnace, you must achieve the elemental balance prescribed by the recipe before the furnace's durability fails.
17935 : Fortunately, synergy furnaces are outfitted with a wide array of features designed to aid the synergist in this demanding task. First, you'll want to confirm the current balance of elements within the furnace and compare it to your desired result.
17936 : Next, you can begin to feed fewell into the furnace to gradually raise the level of elemental concentration. Feeding fewell into the furnace until the required elemental balance is achieved is the most fundamental operation of synergy.
17937 : However, high concentrations of elemental power can lead to volatile and unpredictable reactions. Simply adding fewell haphazardly without making the necessary adjustments is a recipe for only one thing, and that's disaster.
17938 : If you sense that the furnace is on the verge of elemental overload, you'll want to employ the safety lever and pressure handle to prevent an unfortunate accident from occurring.
17939 : You'll also want to mind the laws of elemental ascendancy and opposition. Increasing the concentration of a particular element will cause its counterpart to decrease.
17940 : The furnace cannot sustain its power indefinitely, and will gradually lose durability as the synergy process continues. You'll need to perform periodic furnace repair should the furnace near its breaking point.
17941 : It is also possible to recycle strewn fewell during synergy. While this will not impact the success or failure of the process itself, it will result in a greater amount of salvageable cinder produced as a by-product.
17942 : This cinder is of great interest to our researchers back at the institute. As such, we have introduced a reward system through which quality samples can be traded in for an assortment of synergy-related wares.
17943 : As marvelous an apparatus as the synergy furnace may be, keep in mind that the technology is still in its infancy, and highly unstable. There may be times when accidents occur despite the best efforts of the synergist.
17944 : For your safety, we recommend stepping as far away from the furnace as possible at the first sign of danger. Some synergists claim that giving the furnace a good thwack is also effective in preventing such accidents, but this is pure madness, if you ask me!
17945 : You will also find that there are numerous techniques that can be applied to make the synergy procedure go even more smoothly.
17946 : In many cases, expertise and knowledge acquired through crafting will serve you in synergy as well. To truly master synergy, one must master crafting as well.
17947 : Now let us return to the synergy process itself. As your elemental balance approaches that prescribed by the recipe, the furnace will signal you, and you may retrieve your finished product.
17948 : If the furnace is still holding strong at this time, you may choose to keep working to achieve an even closer balance. The closer you come to the ideal balance, the higher the quality of your finished product will be.
17949 : Indeed, many synergy masters consider these waning moments after the signal to be the time to really show off their skills! Why, if they manage to achieve an elemental surge...
17950 : What's an elemental surge, you ask? Why, it's a miraculous phenomenon that occurs rarely--ever so rarely--upon feeding the furnace fewell.
17951 : The elements react just in the right way, creating a miraculous reaction that brings the level of elemental concentration to exactly the desired level. Truly a boon from the Goddess for any synergist, no?
17952 : ...And that is the synergy process in a nutshell. There's quite a bit of information to take in, so don't hesitate to return any time for a refresher course.
17953 : Much like synthesis, to fashion items through synergy, you will need to follow a recipe. We synergy engineers are always unearthing new recipes, and are happy to share with you those suitable for your level of skill.
17954 : Unlike synthesis, however, a synergy recipe is more than just a list of ingredients. There is also a required elemental balance that must be attained to achieve your desired result.
17955 : Simple recipes involve only small doses of a limited number of elements, but more complex ones require the synergist to skillfully juggle wide ranges of elements in extremely high concentrations.
17956 : The ingredients, you will have to remember on your own. The required elemental balance, however, may be reviewed at any time during the synergy process by observing the readings on the synergy furnace.
17957 : In particular, recipes through which the curious substance known as % can be attached to equipment are creating quite a buzz among synergistically inclined adventurers these days.
17958 : % cannot be attached directly. First, equipment must be prepared by etching an aperture into which an elementally compatible piece of % can then be embedded.
17959 : The type of aperture that may be etched will depend on the piece of equipment. There are also pieces of equipment that, alas, may not be modified at all.
17960 : If you are curious what manner of aperture may be etched into a particular piece of equipment, you need only trade it to me or one of my colleagues.
17961 : As a general rule, the higher the level of the item in question, the more difficult the synergy process for creating an aperture will be.
17962 : You will find that certain pieces of equipment may be etched with multiple apertures. It is, however, only possible to create one aperture at a time.
17963 : Etching requires the use of a corrosive substance we call mordant. Deposit mordant into a synergy furnace along with your equipment, and the process will begin.
17964 : My colleagues and I have a stock of mordant available for sale. The best way to learn is to practice, so if you're curious, we encourage you to purchase some and begin experimenting!
17965 : The difficulty of the synergy process when embedding evolith is decided by a number of factors.
17966 : Such factors include the variety of aperture and evolith, as well as the quantity of evolith you seek to attach. Embedding the first piece is not too difficult a task, but the second and third pieces will not go in so easily.
17967 : To begin the embedding process, deposit your evolith into the synergy furnace along with a piece of equipment with a compatible aperture.
17968 : When etching or embedding, the required elemental balance may be confirmed at any time during the synergy process, so let this be your guide.
17969 : Should you ever wish to remove any apertures and embedded evolith from a piece of equipment entirely, you may do so with an ingredient we call revertant.
17970 : Toss the revertant in a synergy furnace along with your equipment, and its potent powers will restore your item to a pure and pristine state! Be warned, however, that embedded evolith will be lost forever in the process.
17971 : As you are no doubt already aware, synergy makes use of a highly combustible form of elemental crystals that we call fewell. The more complex the recipe, the greater the quantity of fewell required.
17972 : Veteran synergists know well the hassle of having to constantly monitor their fewell supply and procure crystals to replenish depleted stock.
17973 : To free you of such trifling burdens and allow you to focus your mind entirely on your art, we synergy engineers are offering a convenient fewell replenishment service!
17974 : For a nominal fee calculated based upon the current state of your fewell reserves, we will instantly refill you to full capacity.
17975 : That's right--all elements in one simple transaction, directly to your %! What could be easier?
17976 : Looking to fire up your furnace and enter the world of %? If so, you've come to the right place!
17977 : We're proud to offer a supply of the corrosive agent known as mordant for sale. With this, synergy newcomers can hone their skills and outfit their equipment with evolith-capable apertures in the process.
17978 : Mind you, our stock is limited to only the most diluted, readily produced form of the stuff. You'll find that it only has the strength to etch items of relatively low level.
17979 : Etching high-powered equipment requires the use of more concentrated and potent forms of mordant. As quantities are limited, we can offer these only in exchange for cinder.
17980 : Ah, synergy techniques! Those handy tricks of the trade that can mean the difference between a shiny new item and a major furnace meltdown.
17981 : My colleagues and I are always eager to train fellow synergists in a wide range of techniques. We can't do it all, though--you'll need to hone your synergy skill in order to benefit from our instruction.
17982 : Bear in mind that certain techniques can only be imparted to students possessing specialized crafting knowledge. For example, only skilled smiths will be able to comprehend the method for more efficient fewell feeding.
17983 : Accomplished goldsmiths will be able to observe the inner workings of the furnace and stave off potential accidents. You will find that all crafting skills--even those you may not expect--may be applied in some way to support the synergy process.
17984 : Word has it that there are also pieces of equipment that can impart hidden synergy techniques to the wearer. These, too, are said to be only accessible to skilled crafters.
17985 : The moral of the story is this: while synergy skill is important, neglect not your other crafting skills. To become a true synergy master, finding the proper balance is key.
17986 : Synergy remains a young discipline, and researchers back at the institute are burning the midnight fewell in the hopes of uncovering the next breakthrough in our field.
17987 : Research of late is centered around the cinder that is left behind as a by-product of each synergy operation. Their composition, it would seem, has much to teach us of the true nature of the complex elemental reactions that go on within the bellies of these furnaces.
17988 : We've even instituted a reward program for adventurers willing to contribute prime samples in the name of science.
17989 : It would be no exaggeration to say that, to us, cinder is worth more than its weight in gold! Bring it to me or my colleagues--preferably in large quantities--and you're sure to be pleased at what we can offer you in return.

18009 : A life without intellectual curiosity is a life hardly worth living. Should your eyes one day open to this truth, you are free to return.
18010 : I thought you'd never ask! Synergy is both an art and a science: an evolution--nay, a revolution--in synthesis.
18011 : Using % in conjunction with a synergy furnace--the apparatus you see beside me--the synergist wields the power of myriad elements to fabricate a veritable host of potent items.
18012 : What we call % serves to dispense fewell crystals--the lifeblood of the synergy process--whilst also protecting its contents from the volatile reactions that occur within the bowels of the furnace.
18013 : Synergy furnaces have been installed throughout the city for the use of all synergists. The crucible is sufficiently compact and lightweight that you can carry it with you.
18014 : Initiating the synergy process is as simple as inserting your % into a furnace and commencing the infusion of elemental fewell.
18015 : Needless to say, what will happen from there is not quite so simple.
18016 : Successful synergy is contingent upon maintaining elemental equilibrium. The prescribed ratio, of course, will vary depending on the artifact you are attempting to create.
18017 : You can increase the ratio of a particular element by burning the corresponding variety of fewell.
18018 : But herein lies the rub: synergy is a still young science, and the technology we employ remains, shall we say...unstable.
18019 : A bit too much fewell here, a wrong lever pulled there, and the percolating pot will explode, spitting scalding elemental guck every which way to Firesday.
18020 : That's why smart synergists synergize in numbers. Too many culinarians might spoil the broth, but when it comes to synergy, it's the more the merrier!

18652 : Unity Concord is a system promulgated and managed by the Adventurers' Mutual Aid Network.
18653 : Participating adventurers are able to receive a variety of benefits and rewards just by engaging in their everyday activities.
18654 : Unity is a catchall term that refers to the group that participants belong to.
18655 : Unity leaders are individuals who have strong ties to adventurers' activities and are sterling representatives of their home nations.
18656 : Members of the same Unity can converse with each other over great distances through the use of specialized figurines known as %.
18657 : Chat settings may be changed by selecting Status from the main menu, and choosing Unity Info under the Unity submenu.
18658 : You may not always be able to join the chat if too many players are participating at once.
18659 : Those belonging to a Unity are able to undertake special Records of Eminence objectives related to Unity Concord activities.
18660 : The three pertinent categories include shared objectives, Unity leader-specific objectives, and Wanted battle objectives.
18661 : Shared objectives may be taken regardless of which Unity you have joined. These tasks can be undertaken at any time, and change every day at midnight (JST).
18662 : Unity leader-specific objectives are tied to the Unity's eponymous leader and change each week.
18663 : Wanted objectives center around vanquishing particularly heinous foes that terrorize Vana'diel.
18664 : These objectives are of a higher caliber, and thus require currency known as Unity accolades to undertake.
18665 : Shared and leader-specific objectives provide more accolades than run-of-the-mill objectives.
18666 : Vana'diel has always been plagued by nefarious foes pillaging the landscape, but relatives of some of the more heinous ones have been spotted lately.
18667 : The A.M.A.N. has deemed it necessary to eliminate these Wanted targets, and has notified Unity members that they are of the utmost priority.
18668 : A list of these foes can be viewed at any time by selecting the appropriate subcategory under the objectives list.
18669 : Unity Concord representatives are able to provide participants with transportation to the areas where these threats can be found.
18670 : Though tackling the profane will likely require participation of your allies, the objective can be undertaken so long as at least one person has set the appropriate objective.
18671 : When you set the objective and commence the battle, the requisite number of Unity accolades will be deducted from your total.
18672 : Successful challengers will be rewarded with special rewards in addition to the normal sparks of eminence.
18673 : No Unity accolades will be charged should you commence the battle without having the appropriate objective set, but the rewards you can reap from your efforts will be limited.
18674 : You can snatch unparalleled equipment and materials from the slain corpses of Wanted targets.
18675 : An A.M.A.N. specialist versed in arcane harmonization has kindly offered to use these materials to bring out the latent potential in such pieces.
18676 : One of the Unity guides will be pleased to accept certain combinations of equipment and materials to begin the process for you.
18677 : A number of accolades is required for this service, but the precision and accuracy of her methods are without equal, and there is no worry of your equipment being destroyed.
18678 : You can use specified materials to add new attributes to equipment that has been upgraded.
18679 : Utilizing additional materials after adding an attribute can accumulate Reinforcement Points for the equipment and increase its rank.
18680 : Increasing your equipment's rank can boost its attributes, while some equipment can also have additional attributes added later.
18681 : Speak to the Unity guides after gathering the necessary materials for your equipment in order to add attributes to it or increase its rank.
18682 : The first time you add an attribute to a piece of equipment will require the use of Unity accolades.
18683 : It also requires that you first complete a specific Records of Eminence objective.
18684 : The work you request will be carried out on-site by a specially trained Unity guide.
18685 : Completing Records of Eminence objectives as part of a Unity will reward you with Unity accolades in addition to sparks of eminence.
18686 : These accolades not only serve as a symbol of prestige, but can also be exchanged for a variety of services.
18687 : Some of these services include purchasing items, securing battle zones for hunting Wanted targets, fees for strengthening equipment, and more.
18688 : Please note that you may only exchange a maximum of # accolades per week (Earth time).
18689 : You may switch Unities once during the Unity ranking tabulation period.
18690 : This is not a decision to be taken lightly, for switching Unities will cause you to forfeit any benefits you were receiving from your previous one.
18691 : This process requires a fair deal of paperwork, and the A.M.A.N. will charge you an accolade fee based on your rank.
18692 : However, your valorous deeds remain wherever you choose to go, and you will not lose any other accolades.
18693 : Rankings are decided through the combined efforts of each of the Unity's members.
18694 : The A.M.A.N. tabulates all the good deeds done during a period of time and confers benefits on a Unity for the following ranking period.
18695 : Some of these benefits include changes to Unity accolades gained and the effects of equipment earned from Wanted battles.
18696 : Yes, you read that correctly--the attributes of certain equipment will increase in line with your Unity's ranking.
18697 : On the other hand, members of a Unity that finds itself on the lower rungs will enjoy an increase in accolades and capacity points earned to help bring them up to par.
18698 : Additionally, an individual's evaluation is the sum of the accolades they have earned divided by #. A Unity's ranking is the average of all eligible members' individual evaluations.
18699 : The A.M.A.N. does not look kindly on those who only seek to siphon rewards from others' hard work, and thus only confers these boons on those who have collected at least a certain number of accolades.
18700 : Unity leaders may also join you as alter egos for a limited period of time.
18701 : Those with evaluations of # or greater will be able to call forth an alter ego of their leader to assist them in battle.
18702 : Those eligible will be able to use the alter ego from the moment they acquire the appropriate ranking level until the tabulation after the next.
18703 : A leader's alter ego grows in power the higher their Unity is ranked.
18704 : Changing Unities will remove the player's ability to call forth their leader's alter ego at the moment they leave their current Unity, regardless of personal evaluation or remaining time.
18705 : A player will have to work hard in their new Unity and acquire a sufficient evaluation to regain the ability to call forth their new Unity's leader.
18706 : It goes without saying that players must first have acquired a Trust permit in order to avail themselves of this opportunity.

19210 : This is an explanation of the Assist Channel feature, which allows new and returning players to seek help from veteran adventurers.
19211 : You must take on the % Records of Eminence objective before receiving the explanation.
19212 : You must complete % before taking on the % Records of Eminence objective.
19213 : What do you want to learn about? What is the Assist Channel? How can I post a message? What are the requirements? Where can I access it? Tell me about mentor messages. Where can I find mentors? What are Thumbs Up and Warnings? What happens if I am muted? When do my posting rights expire? Nothing for now.
19214 : The Assist Channel is a special chat channel that allows adventurers to ask questions and receive advice from veteran players known as mentors.
19215 : Press the space bar to bring up the text window at the bottom of the screen and type /assistj (your message) or /assiste (your message) to post your message.
19216 : You can also use /aj for /assistj, and /ae for /assiste.
19217 : Additionally, pressing CTRL+Q will display /assistj or /assiste in the text window for you.
19218 : You can change the CTRL+Q shortcut command...
19219 : ...by going to Main Menu > Config > Misc. 2 > Key Assignment > Commands > Chat: /AssistE or /AssistJ.
19220 : It is recommended that you use /assistj (/aj) when posting in Japanese, and /assiste (/ae) when posting in English.
19221 : You must meet one of the following conditions in order to post to the Assist Channel.
19222 : 1. You are a new player You may post messages from the moment you first set foot in Vana'diel.
19223 : 2. You are a returnee As a returning player, you may post messages upon logging in with a character that has not logged in for at least 48 days.
19224 : 3. You are a mentor You may post messages as long as you remain a mentor to other players.
19225 : New players and returnees may post messages until they have been logged in for a total of 48 hours since first receiving their posting rights.
19226 : If you wish to check how long you can continue to post for, speak to an  and choose "When do my posting rights expire?" to see how much time you have left.
19227 : The Assist Channel can only be used in the following areas.
19228 : Available areas: %, %, %, %, %%
19229 : ...%%%%%%%%
19230 : ...%, %, %, %, %, %, %, %...
19231 : ...%, %, %, and your Mog House (Rent-a-Room).
19232 : You cannot post or read messages outside of the areas listed above.
19233 : Even in areas where messages are allowed, you cannot post consecutive messages. Please wait a while after posting a message.
19234 : Mentor messages are accompanied by a flag () marker. This marker indicates the mentor's reliability (Mentor Class) and experience as an adventurer (Mastery Rank).
19235 : As a mentor's Mentor Class increases, the color and shape of the marker will change:  >  >
19236 : A  marker is a sign that the mentor has earned the highest levels of trust from other adventurers.
19237 : The number affixed to the marker is the mentor's Mastery Rank, and indicates how experienced the mentor is as an adventurer.
19238 : The higher the number, the more experienced the mentor is.
19239 : You can check your own Mastery Rank even if you do not serve as a mentor, so feel free to take a look every now and then if you are curious.
19240 : You can check your Mastery Rank by going to Main Menu > Status > Profile.
19241 : If you wish to speak directly to a mentor, you can search for mentors by going to Main Menu > Help Desk > Mentor Search.
19242 : The Thumbs Up feature enables you to let mentors know when their comments proved to be especially helpful.
19243 : Mentors who earn lots of Thumbs Up replies from other adventurers will see their Mentor Class increase.
19244 : Remember to give a Thumbs Up to any mentor you feel helped you out or taught you something useful.
19245 : A Warning is a feature that can only be used by mentors.
19246 : Please use this feature when a post's contents are insufficient or otherwise may be construed as harassment.
19247 : To send a Thumbs Up or Warning to another player, open the Chat Log Window and move the cursor over the relevant message and press the confirm button (Enter key) to bring up the evaluation menu.
19248 : Evaluations can be made for 10 minutes following the designated player's latest post to the Assist Channel.
19249 : You may send up to one Thumbs Up and one Warning per day (Earth time).
19250 : The Mute feature places restrictions on your ability to post, meaning that other players will be unable to see the messages you post to the Assist Channel.
19251 : Please refrain from posting unsuitable content so that the veteran adventurers are not forced to mute you.
19252 : Mute status can be removed by players that have the necessary Mute List access rights, or it will be removed automatically 24 hours (Earth time) after the mute status was enabled.
19253 : You are free to post messages to the Assist Channel until you decide to stop serving as a mentor.
19254 : You may post messages to the Assist Channel until #:# on #/#/#. (Time remaining: Approx. # [sec./min./hr.])
19255 : If you log out while you still have time available, your remaining time will be carried over to the next time you log in.
19256 : You are about to lose the ability to post messages to the Assist Channel.
19257 : You are unable to post messages to the Assist Channel.
19258 : Take on the % Records of Eminence objective from the Tutorial section of the Records of Eminence Menu and speak to the A.M.A.N. liaison.

19326 : A manual describing proper chat manners floats in front of you.
19327 : Read up on which topic? None for now. I don't know what to talk about. How can I get people to like me? What shouldn't I do? What happens if we don't mesh?
19328 : Perhaps consider starting with a simple greeting. Something like...
19329 : Hello, everyone. My name's %. Nice to meet you!
19330 : Of course, injecting your own personal flavor may act as a conversation starter and help people to remember you.
19331 : No matter which route you choose, make sure to always remain polite. There is no better way to start a friendship off on the right foot.
19332 : When speaking with others, it's critical to listen and be mindful of what they say.
19333 : Always talking and never listening may come across as rude.
19334 : Another important point is to always be mindful of the listener. How would you feel if someone said that to you? Think carefully before sending someone a message.
19335 : It also helps to be clear and concise.
19336 : Being vague might cause others to get the wrong impression.
19337 : Be extremely careful when giving out personal information such as your address or telephone number.
19338 : Furthermore, refrain from making disparaging or aggressive remarks.
19339 : Once you are close to someone, you may be more comfortable letting your hair down, but it is strongly recommended that you refrain from any actions that may be construed as harassment.
19340 : After joining a linkshell, you may find that you have difficulty participating in conversation or that your personality is too different from the other members.
19341 : One of your options in such a situation is to inform the linkshell leader and then leave.
19342 : Finding a linkshell that is the perfect fit might not always be easy, but there is certainly a group out there that will match your feelings and goals.
19343 : Once you find those kinds of friends, hold them fast and value them as much as they value you. There is no better way to enjoy life in Vana'diel.

19345 : I refuse to let the Orcs get the better of our kingdom.
19346 : I am certain that King Destin will heed our advice.
19347 : Have you investigated the cliffs in the northeastern section of the Beaucedine Glacier? It must have been marked on Altennia's map for a reason...
19348 : That cliff cannot be easily scaled, so I went back to grab something to help us.

19350 : Saving the knights is our first priority. We must free them before they freeze to death. Meet me at the entrance to Fei'Yin.
